item.title: Indian temple said to grant U.S. visas
item.description: Immigration red tape can be a nightmare. Unless Hyderabad's Chilkur Balaji temple god is on your side.
item.ExtractedText: 1 of 8 8 photos: Worshippers flock to Indian temple said to grant U.S. visas Doing the rounds – People visiting the temple make 11 rounds of its inner shrine in the hope of having their wish granted. If it is, they must return to make a further 108 laps. Hide Caption 2 of 8 8 photos: Worshippers flock to Indian temple said to grant U.S. visas Hindu deity – The temple was built around 500 years ago as a shrine to Lord Balaji, a form of Hindu god Vishnu. Hide Caption 3 of 8 8 photos: Worshippers flock to Indian temple said to grant U.S. visas Student dreams – Several decades ago it gained a reputation among students wishing to travel to the United States who claimed that praying at the temple increased their chances in visa lotteries. Hide Caption 8 photos: Worshippers flock to Indian temple said to grant U.S. visas Success claims – Literature handed out at the temple offers testimonies of success from previous worshippers. Hide Caption 5 of 8 8 photos: Worshippers flock to Indian temple said to grant U.S. visas 'It works' – "My own sister is in Belgium, in Brussels right now, so yes, it does work," one pilgrim, Manjunath Singh, tells CNN Hide Caption 6 of 8 8 photos: Worshippers flock to Indian temple said to grant U.S. visas Prayers answered – "Our lord is answering the prayers," a priest at the temple, S. Rangarajan, tells CNN. Hide Caption
